# Introduction
Strategy is a behavioral design pattern that lets you define a family of algorithms, put each of them into a separate class, and make their objects interchangeable.

[![](https://mermaid.ink/img/eyJjb2RlIjoiY2xhc3NEaWFncmFtXG4gIGNsYXNzIG1haW57XG4gICAgbWFpbigpXG4gIH1cblxuICBjbGFzcyBTaGlwcGluZ1JlYWRlciB7XG4gICAgPDxpbnRlcmZhY2U-PlxuICAgICtHZXRTaGlwcGluZ1JhdGUoU2hpcG1lbnRQbGFuKSAoKlNoaXBwaW5nUmF0ZSwgZXJyb3IpXG4gIH1cblxuICBTaGlwcGluZ1JlYWRlcjx8Li5ESExcbiAgU2hpcHBpbmdSZWFkZXI8fC4uR29qZWtcbiAgU2hpcHBpbmdSZWFkZXI8fC4uSk5FXG5cbiAgY2xhc3MgZGhse1xuICAgIDw8aW5zdGFuY2U-PlxuICB9XG4gIGNsYXNzIGdvamVre1xuICAgIDw8aW5zdGFuY2U-PlxuICB9XG4gIGNsYXNzIGpuZXtcbiAgICA8PGluc3RhbmNlPj5cbiAgfVxuXG4gICAgY2xhc3MgcHJvdmlkZVNoaXBwaW5nUmVhZGVye1xuICAgIDw8ZnVuY3Rpb24-)](https://mermaid-js.github.io/mermaid-live-editor/#/edit/eyJjb2RlIjoiY2xhc3NEaWFncmFtXG4gIGNsYXNzIG1haW57XG4gICAgbWFpbigpXG4gIH1cblxuICBjbGFzcyBTaGlwcGluZ1JlYWRlciB7XG4gICAgPDxpbnRlcmZhY2U-PlxuICAgICtHZXRTaGlwcGluZ1JhdGUoU2hpcG1lbnRQbGFuKSAoKlNoaXBwaW5nUmF0ZSwgZXJyb3IpXG4gIH1cblxuICBTaGlwcGluZ1JlYWRlcjx8Li5ESExcbiAgU2hpcHBpbmdSZWFkZXI8fC4uR29qZWtcbiAgU2hpcHBpbmdSZWFkZXI8fC4uSk5FXG5cbiAgY2xhc3MgZGhse1xuICAgIDw8aW5zdGFuY2U-PlxuICB9XG4gIGNsYXNzIGdvamVre1xuICAgIDw8aW5zdGFuY2U-PlxuICB9XG4gIGNsYXNzIGpuZXtcbiAgICA8PGluc3RhbmNlPj5cbiAgfVxuXG4gICAgY2xhc3MgcHJvdmlkZVNoaXBwaW5nUmVhZGVye1xuICAgIDw8ZnVuY3Rpb24-)

# Example
## Problem
Suppose we're required that our ecommerce website to have multiple options of shipping. Each shipping-option
might have different rates and price. We'd like to show the shipping-price to our users before they check out.

Some shipping-options we'd like to have at the start are:
* DHL
* Gojek
* JNE

In this case, of course we'd need to integrate to each of our shipping-partners differently to fetch their shipping-rates.
Each partner might have different endpoints and protocols.

However, at the end of the day, with all the complexity details of each shipping-partner, what our business-process wants
is just to show the Shipping-Price to our users before they check out.

## Solution
We have identified that what our business really want is just to show the Shipping-Price to our users. So we'll build a
simple contract out of that
```go
type ShippingReader interface {
	GetShippingRate(route entity.ShipmentPlan) (*entity.ShippingRate, error)
}
```

With the contract set, we'll dive into the details and implement all the nitty-bitty parts of integrating to each partner:
* [DHL](https://github.com/gentra/golang-design-patterns/blob/master/strategy/internal/gateway/shippingreadergw/dhl.go)
* [Gojek](https://github.com/gentra/golang-design-patterns/blob/master/strategy/internal/gateway/shippingreadergw/gojek.go)
* [JNE](https://github.com/gentra/golang-design-patterns/blob/master/strategy/internal/gateway/shippingreadergw/jne.go)

Now the details done, we just need to set up a Factory method to select which shipping-partner we'd like to call
```go
func ShippingReaderGw(partner constant.ShippingPartner) internal.ShippingReader {
	switch partner {
	case constant.ShippingPartnerJNE:
		return shippingreadergw.NewJNE()
	case constant.ShippingPartnerDHL:
		return shippingreadergw.NewDHL()
	case constant.ShippingPartnerGojek:
		return shippingreadergw.NewGojek()
	default:
		return nil
	}
}
```
Then execute it
```go
shippingPartner := constant.ShippingPartnerGojek
shippingReader := provide.ShippingReaderGw(shippingPartner)

rate, err := shippingReader.GetShippingRate(entity.ShipmentPlan{
    Origin:               "Jakarta",
    Destination:          "Bandung",
    ShipmentDurationDays: 3,
})
if err != nil {
    log.Println(err)
}
```

In real-world case, the partner-selection might come from user's selection of shipping-option and we might want to use a
singleton instead of repetitively instantiating new `ShippingReader`
